score.title: And here it is...
paragraphs: Arrogant attendings, incompetent interns, nosy nurses, daydreaming doctors... you’ll find all these and more within the walls of Hollywood Hospital. Medicine may be the reason we’re here, but sexy scandals and hilarious hijinks are what the doctor really ordered, and it’s all about how much you can get away with before the chief comes down on you like a ton of bricks. Catch some sleep while you can, and try to stay out of the janitor’s way.
A NOTE ON SETTING

This playset is based pretty much entirely on the TV show Scrubs, and therefore all the characters should be folks you would find in a hospital. This doesn't have to mean doctors and nurses – some of the funniest material might happen between two everyday shlubs who just work at the building. Consider patients, lab-techs, med students, clergy, clinic volunteers, administrators, accountants, lawyer, janitors, security guards, delivery drivers, cafeteria workers, or even just a buddy or brother of someone else who works at the hospital.
This playset works best with the Soft Tilt and Aftermath tables from the Fiasco Companion book.
SPECIAL RULES FOR DAYDREAMING

If you've ever watched Scrubs, you know that the main character's constant daydreaming is a central component of the show. Anytime your character is doing or thinking something metaphorical, such as feeling like a deer in the headlights, or digging their own grave in a conversation, you are encouraged to narrate that as a quick one-note fantasy smash-cut, then jump right back into the action.

Additionally, however, we've included some rules for longer daydream scenes. These rules are intended to make daydream scenes part of the plot, rather than having scenes that become "just a dream" and therefore feel wasted.
CHOOSING SCENES

At the beginning of the game, substitute 4 red dice for 4 of the regular dice rolled for setup. Don't worry about keeping track of which ones are white or black, you'll take them out and put the regular dice back after choosing scene elements.
Any card that uses a red die for one of its elements gets marked. Each marked card must be used in a daydream scene at least once during the game.
If two red dice get used on a single card, it still counts as just one mark. More than one marked card can be used in any given daydream.
PLAYING DAYDREAMS

Daydreams are framed by your fellow players and resolved by you, so start by asking the group to set up a daydream scene for you. You'll be able to participate in the daydream portion, but the other players should control the narration, in the way that you don't usually have control over your own dreams.

When the daydream seems to be reaching a resolution, decide how to wrap it up, then have your character snap back to reality. You now take over the scene, and play out what really happened, while making the daydream a metaphor for reality.
Example
You have a marked relationship with your character's bully. You ask the group to frame a daydream scene involving that card.
The group sets up a scene where you step into the hall and see a dragon. You realize you're dressed as a knight and carrying a sword, and you decide to charge the dragon.
How does the scene go for you?
White die: You run the dragon through with your sword. Hooray! You snap back to reality, and, emboldened by your victory, confront your bully and verbally smack him down.

Black die: You charge the dragon, but it opens its jaws and breathes flame over you, turning you to ash. You snap back to reality and find yourself frozen to the spot as your bully humiliates you and then walks off laughing.

Note that the relationship card was not used directly in the fantasy portion of the daydream, though it was fairly clear how the dragon was metaphorical. However, the group could just as easily have narrated a scene with the actual boss involved.
